intro: Elaphrium inaguense, commonly known as the Inagua rockmoss, is a rare and specialized plant native to the Bahamas. It is a type of liverwort, belonging to the family Porellaceae, and is characterized by its small, flattened, leaf-like structures called thallus. The plant thrives in moist, shaded environments, typically found on rocky substrates in tropical regions. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Elaphrium inaguense is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts in preserving its unique botanical characteristics.
